headline: Korean BBQ Short Ribs (Galbi)
description: Korean short ribs are a favorite, and they're a snap to make at home with this easy recipe. You can even substitute sliced rib-eye or chicken for ribs.

video.name: How to Make Korean BBQ Short Ribs (Galbi)

name: Korean BBQ Short Ribs (Galbi)
recipeIngredient: 3 pounds Korean-style short ribs (beef chuck flanken, cut 1/3- to 1/2-inch-thick across bones)

recipeInstructions.text: Pour soy sauce, water, vinegar, and sesame oil into a large, non-metallic bowl. Whisk in onion, garlic, brown sugar, white sugar, and pepper, whisking until sugars dissolve. Submerge ribs in the marinade. Cover the bowl and refrigerate 7 to 12 hours; the longer, the better.
Preheat an outdoor grill for medium-high heat.
Remove ribs from marinade and shake off excess; discard marinade.
Cook on the preheated grill until the meat is no longer pink, 5 to 7 minutes per side.

review.reviewBody: Delicious!
Excellent recipe! Reminds me of the korean bbq ribs i used to get at Shilla on Wilshire in Koreatown back in the 90s! Very tasty!!!
I was short on time so I only marinated for 4 hours. I followed the recipe exactly otherwise. It was a hit!!!! Whole family loved it.
Hav made other Korean Ribs that came out better.
have made this before with the thin cut ribs and they were much better than the thicker ones i happen to have
Made this for the first time. Followed the recipe and let it marinate for about 24 hours. Family of four devoured 4 lbs of flanken cut ribs. Loved it.
We have made this recipe many times and have found that cooking the meat over a wood fire or charcoal adds a nice smoky flavor that compliments the dish very well.

Delicious! I didn't have any green onions but it still came out great. I also added a few table spoons of honey to this as my family and I find that the extra sweetness balances the spice from the black pepper and garlic very nicely. We grilled these a 4-5 minutes on each side after getting them to room temperate and they were amazing. The slight charring from the BBQ adds that extra something that a slow cooker can't give. I don't think I'll ever use store bought Korean BBQ marinade again.

I tried making this. Followed all the instructions except I think I got lost when it came to the black pepper. I have ground peppercorn and ground black pepper. I opted for the ground black pepper but was weary of the amount so didn’t add the full tablespoon. Can someone after any advice here? I tasted and it was really spicy and bland.
Awesome

Yes I did make a few changes. I used Rice vinegar for the white vinegar. The 1 tablespoon of black pepper was way too much. I used about 1/2 and it was still too much. I added 1 1/2 cup of vegetable stock with 1 tablespoon or corn starch since I was serving with rice and wanted enough liquid. Other than the heat the taste was great. I will make it again with 1 teaspoon of black pepper.

This was so freaking good! My boyfriend loved it, he said it reminded him of real Korean short ribs! I replaced the water with Pepsi. I would highly recommend that! Then I BBQ’ed(coal) them about 4 mins on each side. Will be making these again soon! Next time I might add some sriracha or chili flakes to add some spice.
This was amazing! The flavor is perfect. My only complaint is that the meat wasn’t tender, so I would probably slow roast to fix this

Made it for Easter Sunday BBQ. Big Hit. Voted best by all family and friends. 
I skipped white sugar and used half of brown sugar to make it a bit healthier, but it's still pretty sweet. 
I used more garlic, more onion, and more sesame oil. More flavorful. 
Grilling instruction is also perfect! Thanks!
I love the marinade and I add ginger zest, brown sugar, sesame oil to it. Short ribs are too fatty so I prefer skirt steak!
My husband loves this marinade for the short ribs! We give the bones to our dogs, but love the meat with rice....

This was an amazing recipe! Honestly the best short ribs I’ve ever had. Used all organic ingredients and substituted coconut aminos for the soy sauce (that’s the paleo substitute for soy sauce), and substituted honey for the white sugar. Marinated for about 20 hours. I will make this again...often!
If you like it spicy consider adding hot chili pepper flakes to the recipe. I made a 3 serving size batch and added about 1tsp. The spice level and flavor was amazing

Great recipe, lots of flavor. Definitely recommend a 24 hour marinade. I subbed all the sugar for a few squirts of honey, and added some chili infused olive oil to give it a kick. 
Easy to cook on the BBQ and a family favorite!

I will definitely make this again! I didn’t have short ribs so I used lean pork, the other white meat. I marinade overnight & added sesame seeds to the marinade. I grilled the pork meat to give it the grill marks & then transfer the them to the oven. Turned out delicious!
Delicious~ Enjoyed by whole family
Really delicious! Taste like the Gal-bi from Alaska!
Absolutely delicious. Better than most restaurants!

I only marinated for 3 hours since I got a late start. Also, I cooked it on a ceramic grill pan on medium heat on the stove. 5 minutes on each side and though it was a bit chewier than it might have been with a longer marinating time, the flavor was on point! Delicious.
This was so easy to make and tastes fantastic!
Great tasting marinade ... little salty but I think I used to much soy!!!!

This recipe is fantastic!!! I can't say enough what a great base recipe this is. I loved the green onion garnish as it brings an added flavour to the meat. I used rice vinegar instead of regular white vinegar and it definitely made a difference. Also, I used Demerara sugar instead of regular brown sugar and it definitely brought out more flavours. I didn't have a regular white onion but it didn't seem to make a difference. Next time, I will try adding in either Pepsi or Sprite instead of water and I'll add in some fresh ginger as well. But all in all, this recipe is a slam dunk and tastes just like the short ribs I get at my favourite Korean BBQ restaurant in Toronto. Thank you so very much for sharing!
Delicious! Substituted green onions and added some sesame seeds, otherwise stuck to the recipe. Marinaded for about 9 hours. Definitely a keeper.
I made these for my entire family and everyone loved it! Both my mom & sister were asking for the recipe before the night was done. Highly recommend this recipe.

I had to use regular beef ribs instead of short ribs, because my supermarket was sold out. Because beef ribs can be tougher, I decided to throw these in the slow cooker for about 6 hours on high, and they turned out wonderfully tender. They just fell right off the bone. I added chili oil and ginger, and doubled the garlic, but these still turned out too sweet for our taste. I think next time I'll add more chili oil and decrease the sugar. I was concerned about it being overly salty after tasting the marinade, but the final product had the perfect level of salt. I can't wait to try this with actual short ribs, and broil them instead of slow cooking.
I added fresh ginger to the marinade and let it sit in the fridge for 24 hours. I served the beef with basmati rice and an Asian chopped salad. The family loved it!!

This is a great recipe, and the marinade is excellent. I followed the directions as written except adding some Sprite for the lemony background as one reviewer recommended. Definitely use short ribs, too. I tried it with beef back ribs and it was a wee bit fatty. But that was my fault. This recipe is a keeper!
Loved this recipe! Yum! Will definitely be making this again!

Awesome dish made in a crockpot. I think 1/2 cup of soy sauce would suffice and increase water to 1 cup to make it less salty if made this way. Kiwi is essential and the secret ingredient. traded out sesame oil with sesame seeds (to make less oily) and used rice vinegar and added couple tablespoons of mirin for more authentic flavor. Lastly add potato, carrot and shitake mushroom for ez one pot dish. Serve with rice and garnish with green onion. It's a ez party pleaser for sure!

Made it, and it tasted exactly as I hoped! I thought it was restaurant quality, or at least made by a good chef. I've eaten my fair share of short ribs, as it's one of my favourite dishes especially the Korean BBQ kind. 

One note, be careful how much onion you put in, they say half a large onion, but I found that to be too much (The large onions that are about the size of a orange). Half of the smaller sized ones is perfect!

This is an awesome recipe! I had read a few before choosing this one because it seemed the simplest and I already had most of the ingredient. I only deviated a little - I used light brown sugar and scallions mixed with a small piece of onion I threw in to use up. Also, we broiled the meat since we live in an apartment and don't have a grill. With some white rice and kimchi ordered in we enjoyed a wonderful meal! I will definitely be making this again.

This was an easy recipe to make. I read quite a few reviews, which I used some of the tips and suggestions.
For me I added red pepper flakes and toasted sesame seeds. I didn't have sesame seed oil so I used canola oil. The ribs marinated for about 5 hours. 
I baked the ribs on a shallow pan in foil at 275° for almost two hours. 
I put the remaining marinade in a saucepan adding 3/4 cup more brown sugar. Reduced in half cooking slowly with a constant stir. Added cornstarch and water to thicken a bit more. 
Barbecued the ribs basting with marinade glaze. They were so tender and moist, melted in your mouth.
Mine did not crisp up as much as this picture, but tasted good, I have to get them crisper

Super easy and delicious! I always add some type of citrus to help tenderizing. Other than that I follow this recipe to the letter. We've made these ribs on the BBQ and in the Crock Pot. Both ways is great. Marinating overnight is key.

I have made this so many times, and it has been perfect every time. It is really easy to prepare, as well. I have made it for a lot of different people, who have all raved about it. I've used different cuts of beef including tenderloin tips, sirloin tips, boneless short ribs, bone-in short ribs, and it has always been so tasty. Last night, I baked bone-in short ribs on a rack, in a convection oven setting at 275ºF for about 40 minutes. They turned out really well. Enjoy!
This is so delicious. I made it for a birthday party. It was a favorite.

In case anyone is going...Wow, that's a long time to marinate. Do not cheat the marinate time. If you have TMJ, your jaws will get a workout. I'll rate it 5 stars because I know it'll be good next time.
AWESOME!! I marinated my short ribs for 1 1/2 days...They smelled sooo good after coming off the grill I didnt even have time to take pic. I blinked and they were gone!
This marinade is really awesome! I couldnt find the proper cut on the ribs, but thought the marinade was great! Im trying to think of what else I could put this on! YUM!

Really easy and really good. I did make some adjustments. I added season salt, onion powder, black pepper, and red wine vinegar to the marinade. I also used the marinade once removing the ribs. I simmered it down with some chopped celery, bay leaves and minced onions and used it to drizzle on top of the finished grilled ribs. Once I drizzled the sauce, I put them in the oven covered on 350 to bake for 30 minutes and they came out very tender and full of flavor. This is a keeper. Yum.
So I've tried this recipe twice now, in two very different ways and either way hasn't turned out amazing.

Amazing - and I did it without a BBQ or grill. I only made one substitution: replaced the water with Coke at the suggestion of a friend who makes these all the time. Then marinated for almost 24 hours, braised in a dutch oven at 300 for 4 hours. Removed the ribs, strained, defatted, and reduced the liquid. Brushed it back onto the ribs and broiled for 5-7 minutes per side. First time ever making ribs and it was a knockout.

Absolute perfection! After marinating overnight I browned the ribs in a small bit of oil, placed in the crockpot, simmered the remaining marinade in the same pan to reduce a bit and scrape up the brown bits, then poured over the ribs and cooked on "HI" for 4 hours.

delish! substituted sprite for water. 1/2 low sodium soy sauce and 1/2 coconut soy sauce. dumped it all in the crockpot and simmered on low for 8hrs. was soooo good. meat fell off the bones. ate with egg noodles. leftovers went into the fridge and peeled off the fat the next day. chopped the meat up, removed the bones and ate again over fried rice. can't wait to make it again for company

Really very good. I changed it up a bit. I lightly dredged the ribs in flour salty and pepper and browned in bacon grease. Deglazed pan with beef stock an added with chopped bacon and some of the grease to the liquid and cooked in my pressure cooker on high pressure for 1 hour.

I've had some real Korean Kalbi and this was not nearly as good as the kind in the restaurant, but my family enjoyed it nonetheless. I might try to add some other spices, such as ginger, green onion and sesame seeds to see if it resembles the real Korean taste.

Really enjoy the flavours of this. washed meat before hand after reading a review. Marinaded beef ribs for approx 30 hours. Used pineapple for the last hour to help break down the meat to tenderize it. Worked great. However I made enough ribs to try two different methods of cooking, I've done the grill before and it wasn't operational from the cold weather so I fried them in the frying pan and tried slow roasting in the oven. The oven method did not turn out well. I think they need to be cooked fast. The frying pan was great to cook them. Fresh out of the pan they have a lot of flavour.
Made it as written...minus the sesame oil..I was out. My 14 year old son and I loved it!! Did it in the crock pot and served with egg noodles!!

Tastes great! Even my grandson (age 3) liked it. Easy and quick. I followed this recipe "to a t" and it was fine, although it may be a tad salty for some folks. Just remember, you need to plan ahead for this since it requires some time to marinade.
This was a huge hit. Replaced the water w/ 7/up n added half of a pear (minced). So flavorful, tender & afflicting!

Don't boil your ribs for too long, keep an eye on them or they will fall apart. Putting this sauce on them and then broiling them makes them so good. I've used this sauce recipe on other meats as well. Fantastic!!
fantastic!
The longer this marinates, the better it tastes...Soo good!
This recipe is RIGHT ON. I only marinated the galbi for 30 minutes, and it still tasted amazing. I also used the marinade on chicken, and it was awesome. This marinade is a keeper!

I tried this recipe twice and still do not care for it and do not think it is authentic. I lived in Korea for two years and this recipe doesn't taste like the dish I ate when I lived there. I tried it in the crockpot, as one reviewer suggested, that was terrible and not very flavorful as the crockput ends up having too much water and the meat was tasteless. The second time, I broiled it thinking it would be better and didn't care for the taste of the meat that way either. I marinated it a long time and was very disappointed. I will not make this again.
Made exactly as recipe instructed and loved it. Will be making it again annd again.
That is a family favorite now.......Thanks for the recipe!
EXCELLENT!
This was a great recipe. However I just added some chopped cayenne peppers for some kick.
Family fave

I added chopped green onions and a bit of ginger to make this recipe simply amazing. BBQ the chicken over low heat and during the final two minutes of grilling place the meat over high heat to get a nice crispy taste!

This recipe is unbelievable! I couldn't find beef short ribs so I used pork country ribs. I followed the recipe exactly as its written. my husband loves my cooking anyway, but he raved about these ribs. I made fried rice as a side dish. Wonderful together! I've got them marinating now for tonight. I think I'm going to try to boil some of the marinade and serve a little bit as a dipping sauce with them. I'll edit this and let you know how that turns out. These are perfect!

I LOVE this recipe. It tastes just like the Galbi you have in the Korean restaurants in Koreatown here in LA. I can't always get short ribs with the bone in so the boneless large pack at Costco works just fine. I add a bit of crushed pineapple or minced Kiwi to the marinade to tenderize the meat. My Korean gf gave me that suggestion and it works wonders.
LOVE THIS!!! I cook this recipe all the time for parties. EVERYONE that eats them can not stop eating them. I don't like meat, but I can not get enough of these! YUMMY!! BEST recipe

The flavor of the sauce is unbelievable. I boiled the marinade for a few minutes and poured it over rice. Delicious! While I enjoyed the charbroiled medium rare beef on the grill, next time I think I will use the crockpot for more tenderness.
Family favorite! Followed recipe as is, but only marinated for about 7 hours & they were wonderful. Served with an Asian Slaw & grilled asparagus...delicious!!
Really good - and the marinade was good on pressed tofu as well!
Great but too fatty for BK

This recipe was great. My suggestion would be to marinate for the full 12 hours. I made the recipe almost as writted. I had more meat, so I doubled the marinade, excluding the garlic, onion, and sesame oil. I also added 2 ends of a green onion. I'm not a big sesame oil fan, thats why I didn't include the double amount. Regardless, great recipe. Will definately make again, but marinate longer.
Very easy to make and absolutely delicious. The hardest part is looking for that specific cut of meat, usually in Korean or Japanese supermarkets.

This was a hit with everyone. I didn’t have onion but ended up using chopped green onions instead. I also used a low sodium soy sauce. It turned out delicious over the grill. I will definitely be making this again. Thanks for sharing.

Very tasty, but a little too much black pepper. Sesame oil makes it hot enough - a whole
tablespoon is a little overkill - crock pot is the way to go
Delicious! My husband and I love this sauce and I've been making them almost every week with beef short-ribs. Thank you for sharing!

Marinade is delicious. I highly recommend. 

I had to cook this in the oven (no BBQ) and next time I would do it slightly differently. Last night I just cooked it for 40 mins on 375 degrees but the ribs were still pretty fatty. I like them a little drier so I would cook them at 350 for maybe an hour on a rack (so they aren't sitting in a pool of grease) and then broil them for maybe 5 minutes. I think that would dry them out a little more and they would be a little crunchier. I also recommend keeping a little of the marinade separate from the beef and heating it up to serve with the rice with dinner. Just de-lish!

Sooooo AMAZING!! I used boneless short ribs and followed the remaining ingredients exactly and marinated for 17 hours. The previous comments were helpful. Marinating for longer is better. I made this for a dinner party and everyone loved them. Will definitely make this again!
Simple, quick, and delicious. You have to at least try this once!

My husband and I can't get enough of these! They are fantastic! 
Made exactly as directed. They come out perfect every time.

I made this recipe for the first time and it was a hit. My kids loved it. I also substituted chicken for my husband since he's trying to limit his red meat. I did as the recipe said and it was soooo good.
Wonderful! My 5-year-old triplets ask for second helping.

Loved these ribs! I cooked them in the crock pot on low overnight and warmed them back up with some carrots. I served them with white short grain rice to complete the meal. The best meal we have had in a long time. The sauce was perfect poured over the rice.
Restaurant quality and very Asian taste!

I love this recipe! I follow as directed and serve with rice and green lettuce (Bangja Gui) I make a sauce to go with the lettuce wraps. Soy, sriracha, water, brown sugar, garlic powder, and a lil sesame oil. I don't know the measurements...I just add a lil here and a lil there.
Marinated for 36hours. Could have easily done so for 2 days and the flavor would have been even better.
Great recipe. Didn't have to change a thing. Will definitely make again and again!

My hubby loved this!! I boiled the ribs for about 15-20 minutes before throwing it in the crock pot. Sauce went in (substituted water for chicken stock and pepper for red pepper flakes). Cooked it for about 6 hours and threw in some slice green onions before serving. No leftovers and it was just the 2 of us!

Excellent recipe. I altered it slightly by first braising the ribs in a slow cooker for 4 hours & then finishing on the grill. Served with Asian coleslaw, and it was DELICIOUS. Please see my blog post on this recipe for additional pictures: http://kitchenandcraftadventures.blogspot.com/2011/05/korean-bbq-short-ribs.html
DH accidentally burnt these on the grill, but they were still very good. A keeper.
Absolutely loved it! Made it exactly as instructed except only marinated it for 5 hours and it still tasted delicious! My husband and son both loved it as well. I'll make this all summer long.
I didn't have sesame oil, so used canola oil instead and they turned out great. I will definitely be making these again!

Very Yummy.
Made some alterations for my 3 pounds of boneless short ribs. I reduced the amount of black pepper and sesame oil by 1/2. 
After tasting the sauce mixture, I found it to be too salty and acidic for my liking, so an additional 2 tablespoons of brown sugar were added. It is also the middle of the winter, so bbq grilling was not an option. Instead of slow cooking it as others suggested, I then pan fried it to a medium-rare to get that browning on the edges. Also, instead of discarding marinade, I actually kept it and used it to cook with the meat as well. As the marinade cooked and reduced, it became a great gravy sauce to top the short ribs with.
Whole thing came out very delicious. It's a keeper!
excellent, just like in a korean restaurant
Very delish! I read one of the reviews and it said that this cut is hard to find. Mostly, you can find this cut in Asian markets. Most big enough Asian market carries it.

My one and only korean-style marinade. You don't necessarily have to use shorts ribs all the time (it can get pricey). If lucky, sometimes I would use various types of tender beef cuts that has some kind of fat in it.

Truely a 5 star recipe. Can't go wrong with it the way it's written. I'm in Okinawa and our base commissary always seems to have flanken style ribs for very reasonable prices. So, we have them a couple times per month. An Okinawan lady told me to put an Asian pear in the blender with all other ingredients. (Asian pears are shaped more like an apple and have greenish yellow skin) The pear will tenderize the meat and it produces an unbelievable taste. I've also put pineapple juice and fresh pineapple in the marinade before too.
